lines.text:
[to Duke De Lorca]
The sword is not for a traitor. You'll die by the knife!
But how long will you love me?
Sweet lady, love is not measured in terms of time, only in ecstasy!

[to Queen Margaret]
Like most other men there has always been an imaginary woman in my life. I endow her with all the virtues, I clothe her in perfection. Naturally I search for her in vain. I thought she could never exist except in my mind. Now I find out she does.
All my life I seem to have been stumbling around as if in darkness. I am no longer.
Silence! You have no right to speak to me that way. I forbid you.
But I would never have spoken except by your command.
Then I was wrong to command you. Wrong to believe that you could reform. Or that friendship and loyalty could ever replace your desire for another conquest.
[last lines]
Juan! No more romance, huh?
My dear friend, there's a little bit of Don Juan in every man, and since I am Don Juan, there must be more of it in me!
But you've made love to so many women.
Catherine, an artist may paint a thousand canvasses before achieving one work of art, would you deny a lover the same practice?
Beloved, no power on Earth could've kept me from you. In all this world there's been but one image in my heart, one vision before my eyes...
Yes, yes, go on...
I have loved you since the beginning of time.
But you only met me yesterday...
Why, that was when time began!
May I remind you, my dear fellow, that in a conflict one must choose a side. The middle ground is frequently the most dangerous.
I've been in the middle so many times, your grace... it doesn't disturb me.
a rich full life and the first time he tries to be utterly sincere, what happens?
That's exactly what I'm trying to find out.
Well, mind your own business!
We consider Don Lorca the greatest living duellist in Spain.
That's certainly the mark of a good duellist, you majesty - to be living.
It seems to me Your Grace is preparing for war.
Does the idea frighten you?

Frankly it does. I'm by nature a peaceful man, Your Grace. It's true I've done some fighting in my time, but it's usually been for something worthwhile like, uh, a beautiful woman. To risk your skin for a piece of extra ground - that is terrifying!

[to Don Juan]
The palace has large keyholes. My informer has small ears.

[finding Don Juan with his fiancee]
You'll not get away so easily, senor. You're caught!

[sardonically]
The story of my life!
I asked you that when I was Queen, but I am no longer.
You are. You always will be. I shall be the only one who knew that for just a little while there was no Queen.
[Don de Cordoba has just discovered the famous Don Juan romancing his bride-to-be, Lady Diana. He draws his sword]
You're a disgrace to Spain. And as a loyal Spaniard, I shall wipe out this disgrace!
Oh, stop being so... so *Spanish!*

You can see we have several interesting devices in this chamber. They have the tendency to break a man's will. If the first one fails, we try another until we find exactly the right one to loosen the tongue.
I've heard of men whose tongues have withstood it.
Yes, but they now speak with the tongues of angels.
This is treason!
You will never succeed. The people will rise against you!
Shepherds may change, but sheep remain sheep.

[preparing to fight Don Juan]
I warned you, senor! This time I shall cut deeply!

[unintimidated]
This time I'm wearing my old clothes!
[first lines]

[narrating voice over]
In Europe, as the seventeenth century dawned, mankind was lifting itself from ignorance and superstition.
Who is this?

[to Catherine]
You tell him.
You're here at last. You found me!
Indeed I have.

[to Count de Polan]
Your Excellency, I don't consider myself particularly wasteful or useless. I'm just seeking happiness, the same as any man. Our viewpoints differ that's all.
Her Majesty, Queen Margaret.
Tell me, Don Juan, do you hire men to spread the words of your romantic conquests.
No, Your Excellency, that's a service that's always been done for me free of charge.
You have a ready tongue. It's a pity it's been used in such idle pursuits.
A matter of opinion, Your Grace. Some men prefer the conquest of beauty to the conquest of the throne.

[to Don Juan]
You're no credit to this crown or to our flag.
Next time I shall cut you deeply.
Next time I shall wear my old clothes.
